issues.description: The problem statement's Part 2 text requires messageOnMilk(double milkVolume) (i.e., a method that takes a double parameter and includes the milk volume in its return string), but the UML earlier in the same problem statement, the template usage, and the provided solution all define/use messageOnMilk() with no parameters. This is an internal contradiction in the specification and a cross-artifact mismatch: students following the textual description would implement a different method signature than what the UML, template comments, and solution expect. This makes it impossible to satisfy both the textual requirement and the template/solution signatures at the same time and will confuse students about the correct interface API.
issues.suggested_fix:
Resolve the conflicting specification for messageOnMilk by choosing one consistent signature across the problem text, UML, template, and solution.

Two options (pick one):
1) Keep the parameterless API (preferred because template/solution already use it): Update the Part 2 textual description to require messageOnMilk() with no parameters and adjust the example return string to "[Animal Type] [name] is milked" (remove the volume part). Ensure the problem text no longer references messageOnMilk(double).

2) Adopt the parameterized API: Change the UML, template usages, and solution to declare messageOnMilk(double milkVolume) in the Milkable interface, update all implementations (Goat/Seal) to accept the double parameter and include the volume in the returned string (e.g., "Goat Buttinsky is milked (volume: 1.5L)"), and update any template/Main code or tests that call messageOnMilk() with no arguments to pass an appropriate double value.

Document the chosen API clearly in both the UML and the textual specification so students know the correct method signature to implement.

issues.description: The problem text (Part 2) instructs implementers to provide a method messageOnMilk(double milkVolume) that includes the milk volume in its return string ("[Animal Type] [name] is milked (volume: [milkVolume]L)"). However, the rest of the exercise (the UML earlier in the problem statement, the template usage in Main, and the solution repository) define/use messageOnMilk() with no parameters and implementations returning "[Animal Type] [name] is milked" (no volume). This creates a direct signature/name mismatch: students will be unsure whether to implement a no-argument or a one-argument method and may implement the wrong signature, causing compilation/test failures or confusion mapping the requirement to code.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make the method signature consistent across the problem statement, template, and solution. Two options (pick one and apply everywhere):

1) Keep the no-argument design (matches UML, template usage, and solution): Update the Part 2 textual requirement to say messageOnMilk() (no parameters) and specify the return string as "[Animal Type] [name] is milked" (remove the volume part). This is the minimal change and aligns with existing code and tests.

2) If milk volume is required pedagogically, change the UML, template, and solution to use messageOnMilk(double milkVolume) and update all implementations (Milkable interface, Goat, Seal) and calls (e.g., Main and tests) to pass a double and include "(volume: [milkVolume]L)" in the returned string. This is more invasive but preserves the volume requirement.

Recommendation: Apply option (1) (update the problem text) because the template and reference solution already use the no-argument form, so changing the text reduces student confusion with minimal disruption.
